title: Ticket #78: Splice tests often timeout, but complete successfully later.
description:
Randomly, the larger splicing tests timeout, but afterwards still produce the correct output, indicating they ran correctly. An example is buildid 127306 and specifically this output file for the failed test: output_file.

Dagman has an internal timer of 5 seconds before it checks to see if another job needs to be submitted so a linear chain of 100 jobs would take 500 seconds to execute if everything else worked instantaneously.

However, there is anecdotal statments from collaborators that say scheduler universe jobs aren't run until a successful reschedule_negotiator() call happens and that is capped at 30 second intervals.

I need to check if the combination of these two timers cause long delays if they get too far out of synch.
remarks:
2009-Jan-23 13:40:00 by psilord:

This test submits a dag containing splices which ultimately forms a path 14 nodes long. The "street wisdom" of dagman is that every 5 seconds it checks to see if any jobs have completed and if so, submits the ready jobs (up to a limit, which is greater then the parallelness of this dag).

Here are the raw times for the nodes in that runid: 

In order times of execution of nodes.
Submit   Execute  ID    Node       Terminate Sub->ExTime Ex->TerTime NSubTime
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
10:08:53 10:09:23 365.0 M_A        10:09:25  30          2           10
10:09:35 10:10:03 366.0 M_SD1_S1+A 10:10:03  28          0           9
10:10:11 10:10:12 367.0 M_SD1_S1+B 10:10:12  1           0           {parallel}
10:10:12 10:10:17 368.0 M_SD1_S1+C 10:10:18  5           1           11
10:10:29 10:10:29 369.0 M_SD1_S1+D 10:10:29  0           0           14
10:10:43 10:11:04 370.0 M_SD1_S2+A 10:11:50  21          46          14
10:12:19 10:15:48 372.0 M_SD1_S2+C 10:15:55  209         7           29
10:12:16 10:15:51 371.0 M_SD1_S2+B 10:15:58  215         7           {parallel}
10:16:14 10:18:25 373.0 M_SD1_S2+D 10:18:28  131         3           16
10:18:39 10:19:21 374.0 M_SD2_S1+A 10:19:28  42          7           11
10:19:43 10:21:09 376.0 M_SD2_S1+C 10:21:21  26          12          15
10:19:38 10:21:18 375.0 M_SD2_S1+B 10:21:24  100         6           {parallel}
10:21:45 10:25:13 377.0 M_SD2_S1+D 10:25:15  208         2           21
10:25:26 10:25:47 378.0 M_SD2_S2+A 10:25:50  21          3           11
10:26:01 10:26:26 379.0 M_SD2_S2+B 10:26:41  25          15          25
10:26:15 10:26:36 380.0 M_SD2_S2+C 10:26:52  21          16          {parallel}
10:27:01 10:31:21 381.0 M_SD2_S2+D 10:31:23  260         2           9
10:31:32 10:31:54 383.0 M_B        10:31:55  22          2           9

Total time for execution of the dag is 23 minutes and 2 seconds.

Total time spent in execution is 131 seconds (2.18 minutes). This is the time to run "echo OK", which is the executable and argument for these jobs. Some of this time is overlapping with itself because sometimes 2 jobs were running aqt the same time due to the structure of the dag.

Total time spent waiting for a job to execute is 1565 seconds, or 22 minutes.

This test has a 20 minute timeout, and due to this plus the execution time, blew it.

NSubTime represents the time between the terminate event is written into the log and dagman submits the next ready job. It was taken to be the worst case scenario each time.

So, the question is, why does dagman sometimes spend a long time before realizing it needs to submit the next wave of jobs, and why does the schedd take so long between the job submission and execution for the scheduler universe jobs?

2009-Jan-23 14:42:07 by psilord:

Notice the pretty large gaps of time between starts of some scheduler universe jobs. It seems starting of scheduler universe is not very regular.

2009-Jan-26 17:17:22 by psilord:
When the schedd is under load, You get messages like this: 

01/26 16:09:49 Setting delay until next queue scan to 187 seconds

Which push off the running of any jobs for the next N seconds.

This happens because the timeslice code saw a spike in the length of time it took that handler to run and penalized it to not run for a while. Unfortunately, it does this even if it was a transient spike in load on the machine. So, if you have a deep chain of dag nodes on a machine with somewhat wild load on it, it is possible to delay far beyond the timeout alloted to the job.

Dan and I spoke about this timeslice and under what conditions it would arise, not having claims you can reuse is one of them, which may happen easily the first time a delay happens and you have fast running jobs.

I need to test my setup this under SCHEDD_INTERVAL_TIMESLICE = .99 and see what happens.

2009-Feb-03 15:36:58 by psilord:
I'm having bt wrap the splice tests with personal Condors and have them use SCHEDD_INTERVAL_TIMESLICE = .99 and see if the problem goes away.

2009-Feb-18 10:51:55 by psilord:
Stalled due to debian port

2009-Nov-23 15:26:50 by psilord:
The problems seems to have gotten much better, so I'm deferring this ticket for a while to see if it arises again.

2010-Jan-08 16:16:32 by psilord:
It hasn't been a problem for a long time, so I'm resolving this.
